content.content: MIP68: Monetalis Lusitano: UK Green Economy SME Wholesale Lending  Preamble MIP#: 68 Title: Monetalis Lusitano: UK Green Economy SME Wholesale Lending Author(s): @Allan_Pedersen  Contributors: @Wrongcomma @Julian_Frede  Type: Technical Status: Rejected Date Proposed: 2022-09-03 Date Ratified: n/a Dependencies: n/a Replaces: n/a Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip68-monetalis-vault-v2/13789 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmS7UyQT   References  Monetalis MIP6 Greenlight Vote RWF Risk Eval MIP65: Monetalis Clydesdale Monetalis Evolution   Sentence Summary MIP68 is a self-contained collateral onboarding MIP that will onboard and activate a RWA vault backed by the assets of a trust arranged by Monetalis.  Paragraph Summary MIP68 onboards a RWA Vault backed by the assets of a trust arranged by Monetalis. It brings about a RWA structure that can onboard a specific Green Economy SME lending strategy in the UK, but designed to be flexible enough to start as platform for adding other underwriting teams and executing other lending collateral strategies efficiently. And share structure oversight and design features with MIP65.  Component Summary MIP68c1: Specification of the Proposed Structure and Contemplated Collateral Assets This component describes the details of the structure that Monetalis proposes to onboard as collateral, and the details of the collateral Monetalis will acquire. MIP68c2: Vault Financial Terms and Parameters This component outlines the key financial terms of the vault and legal structure hereof. MIP68c3: Technical Details This component contains the data and instructions necessary for the unambigous technical execution of the collateral onboarding. MIP68c4: Debt Ceiling Gradual Increase Mechanism This component describes an automatic process that increases the Debt Ceiling of the vault further once the first portion of debt has been used.  Motivation Monetalis submitted a MIP6 proposal late October 2021 and received a positive Greenlight vote in late November 2021. Based upon recently received feedback, work done within Monetalis in this period our vault proposal has been redesigned to what is proposed under this MIP. The intention of Monetalis to support Maker’s aspiration along a broad number of dimensions remains:  Help the continued professionalization of RWA operations and integration between TradFi/Maker. Contribute to scalable growth of diversified, high-quality RWA collateral. Operationalize the Clean Money vision. Operationalize an entrepreneurial underwriting team Model. Create and operationalise a high-quality on-chain/off-chain TradFi/DeFi integration point.  The proposal should be seen as connected with MIP65 in accordance the strategy outlined in Monetalis Evolution  Specification / Proposal Details  MIP68c1: Specification of the Proposed Structure and Contemplated Collateral Assets  Structure The following legal structure will be used. It is a feedback adjusted version of the previous proposal. It continues to be a simple, plain vanilla, UK traditional securitization structure for this Asset class.  1338×558 99 KB  This structure is functionally separated as follows and parameterized in the following sections.  1359×572 191 KB  The final documents underpinning the proposed structure will be finally designed and agreed in collaboration with an external legal counsel appointed by Maker. Structure This structure, beyond allowing Monetalis to start our Green Economy SME wholesale Lending business, is flexible enough to allow Monetalis to scale in a number of ways in practice:  We can sponsor/incubate new, more innovative, underwriting teams focused on Maker relevant lending segments. These could be implement simply via signalled changes to Strategic Credit Guidelines and, potentially, Vault increases - a capability easily extendable to include the EU market. We can reuse/clone our TradFi/Maker integration point (BVI trust/trustees/Governance package/Bank/Auditor/Accountant etc) to support execution efforts such MIP65 Clydesdale and other potential arranged collateral. Over time, with multiple collateral types and situations tested against this structure —and continued improvements of the structure—, components/processes that can beneficially be moved on-chain will naturally reveal themselves and be executed upon. This means that Maker (via MGB) can ask for the Bond to be run-off at any time and for whatever reason. This means the usual complex covenant rules, allowing the buyer of the Bond to redeem the Bond for certain breaches, are not needed. It puts all power in the hands of Maker and transaction costs (particularly exchange rates). The funding provided under the Bond is strictly constrained by the Strategic Credit Guidelines, which can be adjusted from time to time in agreement between Maker and Monetalis via a signal. This Bond constructs, under current UK and BVI, a situation of zero withholding tax on the PIK interest at the outset. Over this year we will complete a listing of the Bond, at which point all payments from the Bond will be on a zero withholding tax basis, in line with UK securitization standards for non-UK institutional investors. This means interest will accrue in the Bond until the above listing is accomplished and monthly interest payments can resume. In calculation of collateral value, defaults are deducted. Defaulted receivables are defined as follows:  “…any Receivable which becomes 90 days or more overdue from its original due date; and in respect of which the related Debtor is in liquidation, administration, receivership or bankruptcy (or analogous proceedings), or legal proceedings have been commenced for its recovery or which have been written off as uncollectible in accordance with the Credit and Collection Policies….”  The Attestor/Attestor Committee appointed in MGB will have information and Audit rights on the Bond instrument. The Credit Committee, which approves all credit taken on to the Bond, will require a unanimous yes for an approval. Three persons will be on this Committee, one of which will be an independent industry party. MGB (i.e., the Attestor) will have the right to approve/reject this independent credit committee member as he/she is proposed by Monetalis. 2. I’m taking a step back to evaluate this MIP since I think we are in uncharted territory. My reply is not specific to Monetalis. I’d like to assist the community in understanding what the CES Core Unit would do if we decided to do a technical implementation such as this. This MIP falls outside of the current collateral onboarding process so I have to assume I may not have the support of any other CUs. Core units are independent and the details are up to each CU on how to best implement their mandate. For me, a mandate is what I proposed during my Core Unit onboarding and that which has been ratified with the community. I went back to review the CES Core Unit MIP to reflect on our mandate in relation to this proposed MIP and the context of this situation. The key points I’d like to identify are:  Dai supply, enablement, and operationalizing the process Ensure the stability and security of the ecosystem  Let’s dive into the Implementation for this proposal. Please understand the MIP21 isn’t plug and play and months of implementation to onboard collateral has shown us this. The goal is to operationalize the process but we’re not there yet. It takes time to work through enough MIP21 deals to see the patterns to iterate on the code, freeze it, secure it, and then reuse until we iterate again. With a MIP21, there are some significant questions and the answers to these questions impact the technical implementation.  How do we legally bind the representation of the collateral to a token? How do we deal with pricing and oracles? How do we deal with liquidations? How do we deal with Emergency Shutdown? Based upon code changes in the implementation, is an audit required?  In our experience, to do a proper technical implementation, we rely on the domain expertise of business, legal, and risk people and teams to help us answer our questions and provide clarity. In this case, I would need to access or hire third parties to represent the interests of MakerDAO. Part of our mandate is the stability and security of the protocol so CES would need to publish a variety of assessments based upon third party analysis and the actual implementation. In addition, operationalizing includes managing our collateral. I am in the process of setting up Collateral Operations where my Core Unit will be facilitating the process of maintaining the health of our collateral. In order for this to be effective, there has to be clear onboarding metrics, before onboarding, so we can manage to them. We are making progress toward publishing those metrics in the April governance cycle with our proposed MIP, MIP6c-3SP2: Modify the collateral application form. The metrics will follow in the next several weeks for review and feedback. Last, the other real practicality has to do with relative prioritization when it comes to getting work completed. When it comes to collateral onboarding, I have to ask, what is the most important work for my team to be doing this sprint? The answer to the question is dependent upon a lot of very competent people understanding the pros/cons of each collateral in the queue. I’m not sure who understands this better than the current CUs. My mandate and job is to onboard and manage collateral. I want to figure out how to do this as best as possible. I hope this response is helpful for the community to understand some of the realities behind the scenes and considerations when onboarding collateral.

The incubating Legal and Transactional Services core unit (LTS) requests consideration of the following questions/observations on MIP68: Monetalis Vault v2. It is likely that many of these questions/observations will be ultimately addressed in the transaction documentation process. We are providing them now in the interest of furthering the discussion at the appropriate time. LTS notes that there may be further comments based on the actual transaction documentation. LTS has not reviewed any of the actual transaction documents other than early drafts of the BVI trust (based on the greenlit MIP6 application). The initial review of the BVI trust and our joint discussion with external counsel on Monetalis V1 did not raise any “red flag” concerns. However, that review was not completed at the time - as aligned with @Allan_Pedersen - in order to manage legal expenditure. MIP68c1: Specification of the proposed structure and contemplated collateral asset Structure Monetalis is kindly requested to pay for Maker’s external legal fees. I would be pleased to further develop a budget with Monetalis that reflects reasonable assumptions. Arranging Alpha Structure It may be prudent to clone (not re-use) the TradFi/Maker integration point in respect of other collateral. This can be discussed on a case-by-case basis. LTS supports the concept of moving components and processes on-chain. Monetalis to please consider how the collateral valuation process, including anonymized loan performance may be digitized on-chain. Collateral Assets UK Bond Structure How has Monetalis modeled calculation of the “Annual Profit-share”? Please confirm whether or not the “Annual Profit-share” will be hedged? Please confirm that Monetalis will bear the cost of any FX conversion in respect of the “Annual Profit-share”. The “Annual Profit-share” calculation should be spelled-out to ensure consistency in application. Also, Monetalis should pay for any FX conversion in respect of the “Annual Profit-share”. Also, the definitive documents should provide the date by which Monetalis pays the “Annual Profit-share”. Monetalis to please confirm that interest payments will not be made after the listing. The bracketed text “retained until listing” is unclear. A 50 year duration is exceptionally long. What is the rationale for such a long-term facility? What is Monetalis’ proposed management transition plan on the assumption that current management will have retired? Maker token holders owning an interest in Monetalis should recuse themselves from a liquidation and/or termination decision. How does management “reinvest” 90% of management’s profit share? Will these funds be in a secured reserve account as a first-loss buffer? From a modeling perspective, when does Monetalis anticipate that it will satisfy the 1% target? The collateral valuation metric is very simple and simply aggregates the outstanding principal, interest and fees in respect of each receivable. The collateral valuation metric does not appear to incorporate yield curves, prepayment rates, expected default rates, and other generally accepted parameters. There may be generally accepted accounting standards that provide guidance/criteria on loan portfolio valuation. It may be appropriate to include other reasonable covenants, including general financial covenants, ensuring the separation of the UK SPV from Monetalis, etc. It may be appropriate for the compliance audit to be completed on a more regular basis (e.g. quarterly) to ensure more regular transparency on the underlying collateral. Monetalis ought to better define its proposed hedging program. For instance, what is the anticipated cost for hedging and are these hedging expenses paid in priority to interest and principal? What hedging tools will Monetalis use to manage the currency risk? How will the currency hedges be structured to address a demand for liquidation (what is the anticipated term)? Who does Monetalis anticipate using as the currency hedge counterparty and what is the credit profile of this counterparty? Presumably any payments made under the hedging arrangements will be paid to a secured account to support the repayment of amounts due. Is there intended to be any additional collateral security - security interest over accounts, profit share, hedge agreements, other? Key Design Choices in Bond The on-demand nature of the bond allows Maker to request repayment of the bond at any time and for whatever reason. However, an on demand bond may actually shift power to Monetalis on the basis that Monetalis calculates that the Maker community is less likely to demand repayment for no reason. While the bond may not require the “usual complex covenant rules, allowing the buyer of the bond to redeem the Bond for certain breaches”, it may be appropriate for there to be certain basic covenants and related events of default. The breach of any one of these covenants (and Monetalis’ failure to cure) should trigger a potential event of default. The remedies could include, in addition to on demand liquidation, more oversight of Monetalis’ operations and the underlying portfolio. Unlike purely digital assets, real world assets tend to require more nuance upon the occurrence of an event of default and discretion in the exercise of rights and remedies. Is there any risk that the bond will not be listed and thus not benefit from zero withholding tax? The Credit Committee requires unanimous consent for all credit approvals. Is the same decision-making threshold applied for non-credit approval decisions (actions taken in respect of the underlying loans management (for example, triggering an event of default, consenting to a waiver, etc.))? MIP68c4: Debt Ceiling gradual increase mechanism It may be more appropriate for the debt ceiling increase to be based on the performance of the underlying loan portfolio and not simply Monetalis’ ability to make loans.

The RWF Core Unit offers the following updated observations on the MIP68: Monetalis Vault v2. RWF has already provided a Collateral Onboarding Risk Evaluation for the prior version of Monetalis MIP6 which is linked below. Monetalis MIP6 - Collateral Onboarding Risk Evaluation RWF believes that the Monetalis proposal presents significant risk to Maker in terms of both Facility Risk and DAI Stability Risk.  Facility Risk: Monetalis underperforms and Maker incurs a significant loss on its loan DAI Stability Risk: the market views the collateral backing the DAI as risky due to significant weaknesses in its asset managers, assets and/or investment structures  RWF utilizes two key standards that are noted below.  Investment Grade risk is defined as being highly likely to repay the loan with timely interest and principal. Historically Investment Grade debt has averaged less than 1% default annually. Arm’s Length Transaction is where parties agree to do business, acting independently and in their own interests. When reviewing whether a given proposal would be an Arm’s Length Transaction, RWF asks, would this be funded in the real world? And if it would not be funded at the current terms, what terms could the Proposal be funded at?  Facility Risk Assessment As noted above, RWF assessed Facility Risk in the Proposal, covering Manager Risk, Asset Risk and Structural Risk. Significant deficiencies in any of these three areas would cause a senior loan in the structure to be non-Investment Grade.  Facility Risk Assessment: Manager    Monetalis’ principals lack experience as credit fund managers as compared to their competitors. Neither one appears to have experience as a private credit investor in asset finance nor a track record in the field. Table One shows that the senior investment managers at Monetalis’ competitors average over fifteen years in private credit investing. RWF research has also indicated that first time credit fund managers usually cannot raise investment capital without significant experience in the field with a credible track record.   Monetalis is a startup asset manager that has not originated any loans to date and has an unproven business model. As such they will need to build out and scale their platform quickly and hire personnel across all key functions, including sourcing, underwriting, portfolio management, compliance, reporting, audit and finance/accounting. And taking such a position seems to be outside the CU’s ambit of facilitating and assessing the onboarding of real-world asset-related MIPs - not taking positions and attempting to further or hinder them and certainly not negotiating deals (if that were happening, which I am not suggesting). I can’t speak for RWF, but in this regulatory environment, I certainly wouldn’t want to be seen exercising material, executive discretion. I’d leave that to token holders. So no, RWF should not be a rubber stamp - it shouldn’t be any stamp. It should present its assessment, positive and/or negative, and then let MKR holders vote. As to your points about discussing conflicts, sure, they can be and should be discussed. But, from a token holder perspective, CUs and other DAO contributors are beholden to and empowered by MKR holders after all, my concerns regarding conflicts of interest rest almost solely with those CUs and contributors - not other MKR holders. I already understand that all MKR holders will be voting in their self-interest at all times - that self-interest may be financial, philosophical, political, ideological, egotistical, myriad other things, or a combination thereof. So, I don’t care - not when Monetalis-interested MKR token holders vote for Monetalis, not when it’s a similar situation for crypto-native collateral, not when it’s a D3M candidate, not when it’s an ETH maxi voting on wrapped BTC, or what have you. One takes note of the proposal, expecting interested MKR holders to vote in its favor, and acts accordingly. What I don’t expect as a MKR token holder is that the CUs or other contributors will be acting in their self-interest when they perform work for the DAO. This is the crux of agency law. This is where self-interest can become a conflict of interest - everything in the previous paragraph is not a conflict. It becomes a conflict when a person’s self-interest conflicts with an otherwise legally-imposed interest/duty, or DAO-imposed interest/duty in this case. My indirect investment interest in Monetalis does not necessarily conflict with my interest as a MKR holder - nor do I expect they ever will. They influence each other, but they do not necessarily conflict as contemplated by legal and agency conflicts of interest principles. Now, if one were a facilitator with a self-interest in a given MIP’s underlying entity - then there’s a conflict. That self-interest (in the MIP company) would conflict with the interest imposed upon the facilitator (by the DAO), namely to act in the DAO’s best interest. So, to [mis]use a common syllogism - all conflicts of interest involve self-interest, not all self-interest creates a conflict. If self-interest disqualified one from voting, why ever participate in that governance process…ever? So let’s take your corporate governance analogy - I admit maybe my general democracy one was too broad. Though, while this situation may be cursorily akin to traditional corporate governance (which I would argue for a number of reasons is inapt and an unwise analog), even there shareholders get to vote, self-interest notwithstanding. If I once owned Coca-Cola shares (minority stake) and Minute Maid shares (minority stake), for instance, and have no other legal duties to the companies, I don’t have to “recuse” myself or otherwise abstain from voting on either side of that merger. If I held a majority stake in either, I might have to disclose that stake depending on relevant rules, regulations and law. But, I still get to vote. Conflicts of interest controls and independence protections primarily apply to and concern those with legal duties to a company, i.e. the directors, managers and employees (to a lesser extent) of Coca-Cola and Minute Maid. And again, the solution to any potential conflicts of interest in the corporate realm is typically disclosure of those conflicts prior to any relevant actions and not i) recusal, which is a voluntary concept, or ii) quasi-coerced revocation of votes, which seems to be the suggestion here. As for litigation between shareholders - I don’t really see a rash of holder v. holder litigation related to conflicts of interest. There are proxy fights and fights for control all the time, sure. That said, generally speaking, the valid grounds for any lawsuit can’t be “the other shareholders’ voted in their self-interest” - at least not in any I’ve worked on, been exposed to or am aware of. Grounds for a suit would require conduct, motivated by that self-interest, that violates the law, corporate charter or corporate by-laws. Nothing of the sort is suggested here. Another point here is that there seems to be an assumption - explicitly stated in Discord - that MKR holders who have financial interests in MIP candidates are somehow incentivized to enrich that MIP candidate at the expense of MakerDAO. I personally think that assumption is unfounded and unlikely to be true. First, the assumption rests on any such person placing primacy on the MIP candidate over MKR. Economically and financially, that entirely depends on the size of someone’s comparative and relative interests in both. Ideologically and emotionally, one can’t possibly know unless the person states it, but then it’s known. It also assumes bad faith on the part of any such person, and that the person does not see and believe in a mutual benefit to MakerDAO and the MIP candidate. But on the same token, if the assumption is accepted generally, then we should operate the DAO as if all CUs, facilitators and delegates are out to strip the DAO of its assets in order to enrich themselves and thus shouldn’t be permitted to participate in the DAO outside their very limited mandates. It doesn’t work there either - we couldn’t function and nothing would get done. It’s just a quizzical and seemingly confrontational assumption to make in this ecosystem, where the vast majority of people seem very dedicated to growing DeFi, generally, and MakerDAO, specifically, and have put a lot of time, money and effort into doing so. TLDR - The Monetalis debate and vote, my indirect interest notwithstanding, can and will go how it goes - and I will stand by the result regardless. RWF should remain neutral in its facilitation and analysis of MIPs within its purview - and maybe they completely are and I’ve misread the situation. But, the point remains that continued gatekeeping-like behavior by CUs - and inserting an MKR voting restriction into a live, non-procedural  MIP discussion is gatekeeping at best, and at worst is an attempt at managerial capture (which I’m sure is not the case - puts them square in the regulatory bullseye with regard to issues of control, regardless of concerns regarding mandate scope creep. Lastly, Proposing or even suggesting that MKR holders should recuse themselves or have that forced upon them due to their self-interests, real or perceived, fundamentally misunderstands “conflicts of interest” concepts and, if adopted, would upend the foundations of decentralized governance.

MIP68/LUSITANO: INFLATION & RECESSION The world is brimming over with uncertainty: We have inflation and central banks are working on pushing it down to its 2% target - flexing both its balance sheet as well as its rate setting muscles. The key questions are how far do the central banks have to go to quell inflation? and will it push the world into a recession in doing so? The central banks instruments are blunt and their transmissions into the financial markets and overall economy hard to predict - we have to remember a big part of the transmission comes indirectly - i.e. central banks action sets provide signals and the markets react with expectations of where the central banks will push the economy and markets. I like the common mental central bank analogy of a person walking a dog using a very long leash (and very long indeed now with the amount of money printed today). We won’t try to predict where the world is going - that would be hubris of the highest order - but we do want to present to the community what would happen to Lusitano business in a state of inflation (a continued increase in product and service prices) and/or recession (a decrease of economic output). This is not the first time the asset class has hit points of crisis and so we know, reasonably well, what levers to pull and how we navigate safely through such periods of turmoil. We will go through this in some detail, but to foreshadow: wholesale funding of non-bank lenders focused on senior, secured lending is, at origin, structurally designed to build “All-weather” portfolios and franchises with good returns. . We are primarily concerned about two risks:  Credit Risk (“CR”): Catastrophic Principal losses from default Return Risk (“RR”): Extended periods of Poor Returns (compared to risk free rate)  To manage these risks we have a large range of “defences” in our business model.  Lines of Defence Lusitanos principal line of defences against CR and RR are:  A/ A tall and wide stack of capital, real assets and required financial remedial actions ahead of Lusitano exposures  1600×967 350 KB    The basic capital stack we have explained several times, but just as a refresher:  100 USD end-borrower Loan Secured on Asset to a maximum of usually 50% to 80% of asset value (downward trending LTV in market now) Monetalis funded USD 80 of the loan and Originator fund USD 20. The Originator funds on a first loss basis So an ultimate asset collateralization ratio - between Asset and Monetalis loan is 100/0.5/80 = 250% to 100/0.8/80 = 160%    Monetalis security is not only restricted to the above capital stack, in particular we note the following controls/rights, capital buffers and remedial actions:   OWNERSHIP OF LOAN: When a loan is funded by a lender, the ownership of that loan (along with its receivables and security over asset) is transferred to Monetalis;   SECURITY: In the unlikely event of Monetalis having to take ownership of a portfolio, Monetalis will have the right to collect against the underlying security for a loan. The typical security for our loans are hard assets;   DEBENTURE ON OVERALL PORTFOLIO: This means that whilst Monetalis owns all loans individually, any individual loan losses can be deducted against the performance of all other loans in the portfolio. As Monetalis will only fund lenders that have historically maintained defaults of less than 1%, and each loan funded by Monetalis will not typically be greater than a few percent of an existing portfolio, this debenture adds a substantive capital buffer to the Monetalis portfolio.   CROSS-GUARANTEES ON LENDER: When a new facility is granted by Monetalis to a lender, the lender will be requested to maintain a minimum reserve of retained profits. Monetalis will have a cross-guarantee on these and could call on this reserve to cover any loss of capital. Again adding another substantive capital buffer to the Monetalis portfolio.   REPLACEMENT PAPER: Monetalis has a right to request any defaulting loans be acquired by the lender at full price and replaced by a performing loan. This requirement generally acts as a nice pruning tool that keeps a portfolio in-line in most circumstances.     This all in all, means a crisis would need to strike very deep to ever touch our positions. It ensures our CR is kept exceptionally low.  B/ The “at-will” funding and acceptance - on portfolio and individual loan basis. We have two key sets of data sources and monitoring processes that reduce CR and RR.   INDIVIDUAL LOAN UNDERWRITING & MONITORING When a new facility is agreed, the lender, its products and all the covenants associated with the facility are set up on our IT platform. When a lender requires funding for a loan, they will submit all the relevant details and upload the associated documentation onto the platform. The details for each individual loan that is proposed for underwriting by a lender under a facility agreement are reviewed to ensure it meets our credit guidelines (otherwise it is rejected). This data is reviewed weekly by portfolio manager and monthly by credit committee for trends and concerns. Increase in volumes or more “close to limits” cases or higher rejection rates would be concerning and require investigation. Such investigation would lead to potential immediate changes in the credit facility - increase of interest rate if market is going that direction and/or sharpening of underwriting criteria if warranted.   MONTHLY COLLECTION, DEFAULT AND PORTFOLIO MONITORING Our platform has an Open Banking API with the collection accounts, enabling our system and our team to have direct line of sight of all collections and disbursals.  From all portfolios we get monthly performance data. This is reconciled by our system against the expected collections and the bank account data, It is then reviewed by the credit committee to recommend changes in the facilities. These may be to constrain or even entirely cancel facilities. Any breaches of facility covenants, any semi or non-performing loan are flagged in our system. Providing our team with the relevant breaches, the latest borrowing basis figures and a list of demands for the lender required to cure any of the breaches (including using the “replacement paper” remedy).   Overall, the fact that we have all data at our fingertips and necessary monitoring capability - and the legal ability to make changes as we see fit in the credit facility - are major reasons for why we can reduce CR and RR in dynamically changing environments as inflation and/or recession would constitute. We can follow interest rates as they go up or down (beyond the variable rate mentioned in D/) - and we can contract and expand portfolio acquisitions as we find prudent.  C/ On-site, Lender Audit - at least quarterly - and ad=hoc From experience we know that when markets get challenging to operate in, this is the time where lenders/originators have the hardest time in terms of changing to new realities and ensuring their operations - in particular underwriting and collections - stay within their guidelines and/or make appropriate changes to such guidelines and stick to following them. It is therefore vital to use direct, on-site audits to help these lenders stay on the straight and narrow, at least quarterly, and likely on a more frequent ad-hoc basis if markets and guidelines are changing faster. These audits review guidelines vs actual implementation on underwriting, cash management and collection. Do substantive sampling of underwritten loans, their documentation and collections. And may do a deep dive into defaulted loans and their collection efforts etc… These audits are vital for managing lender/funder alignment asymmetry particularly in dynamic markets where things so easily can veer off-track. It is a key tool in ensuring CR is kept inline. For prudence and good governance, we have these audits carried out by experienced, independent external teams of auditors.  D/ Variable Rate Facilities with lenders The principal RR reducer is the fact that all Facilities provided to Lenders are variable rate connected to BoE bank rate. I.e. we agree a starting interest rate that is then automatically fully adjusted by any BoE base rate movements. Important to note that this adjustment happens across the portfolio (i.e. both current and new loans). The graph below shows the BoE Bank rate movements - as you can see ultimate facility interest rates have moved upwards since the beginning of 2022 and are expected to grow further (as BoE predicts more is needed to curb inflation).  1600×684 51.7 KB   E/ Strategic Resilience Choices: We deliberately - particularly in these market circumstances - select lenders and credit markets that are very likely to perform through a crisis - helping reduce CR. We, in particular, look for:  Lenders that has been through crisis successfully   Most of the lenders in our pipeline will have gone through market turmoil and downturns brought by events such as the Financial Crisis, Brexit and COVID; We want to see the Lender having performed across these crisis without loss to senior - and very limited overall on their portfolio We, in particular, review their ability to collect from semi-performing and non-performing loans that may have accrued during a crisis. We want to see substantive success herein for us to consider providing a facility   Credit markets that are less sensitive to cycle/crisis: We have focused on products, industries and security that have remained resilient through downturns. As examples:   Professional loans, i.e. loans to doctors, dentists, opticians have seen no negative impact in terms of arrears or defaults during the recent COVID pandemic or any previous crisis; Financing of leasing of hydrogen-powered buses to city councils for city bus route operations. The bus still runs during a crisis. Social/Retirement housing. Massive underlying core undersupply in the UK, and buyers/funders (councils, mutuals, insurers/pension funds etc) who will continue to act with a long-term focus during a crisis.  As part of these reviews we also look at the stability of underlying asset value. Its value and liquidity needs to be not materially compromised during a crisis.  F/ Management Team experienced across cycles Our Portfolio Manager, Hywell, has 15 years on the clock with no losses of senior positions and built and managed portfolios of more than GBP 200M for two large wholesale funding banks in the UK. And our Credit Committee Chair, George, has 30 years+ in the market as CEO for Santander and ABN Amro UK finance units and other roles . Allan has 20 years in investment committees and boards from private equity and financial institutions - and Alessio has over 15 years experience in Financial Services, with the last eight years in Executive positions in the non-bank lending market, This means we have a decision making team that has seen and operated during a crisis - and, as such, knows what to look for and is unlikely to under- or over-react in these situations.  G/ Green Economy Program = Resilience In our view, companies who borrow, and invest, into activities/assets aligned with long-term Climate Change/Green Economy goals, in times of a potential recession, are very likely companies with sufficient short (and long-term) financial capacity, resilience of business and strategic foresight to position themselves well for coming out of a potential crisis, where one might expect the pressure to move more aggressively down a Green Economy path would substantially increased. As such we actually see this implicit screening of companies and lenders in respect of their commitment towards a long-term Green Economy alignment and our Green Economy lending Program as a signal of health - and ultimately a more resilient credit risk. So we do see our Green Economy Program screening as part of our CR reducing efforts. That concludes our line of defence description. Let’s now consider inflation and recession effects  Dynamics of Inflation & Lending In an inflationary environment we have arguments pushing both ways in terms of effects on lending: businesses have more pricing power, but supplies are also more expensive and demand may go down. People constrain spending, but, on the other hand, might do well in taking out loans as rising inflation hollows out fixed interest rates. Etc. However, general consensus, is that the net effect on lending/banking is mainly driven by rate of change in, and the level of, inflation - and it goes something like this:  A/ Net effect of Modest Inflation - even long term: Say within the 5% or so, the net effect is overall positive on lending. Basically net interest margin will be rising - lenders pass on the effect of inflation to their customers. There is no material increase in defaults and it is centred around the higher risk portions of debt (where you might say this situation is priced into the lending cost over the cycle): low income, unsecured (credit card) etc… I do hope you note that Lusitano does NOT at all work in that end of the credit spectrum - in short we’d benefit from a modest inflation. It is unclear whether the credit market will long-term expand, stay the same or contract in this situation. The short-term effect of inflation is usually some level of contraction, because banks pull out of several credit markets to reprice and rethink underwriting (you see the mortgage market in the UK being completely overhauled these weeks). They are concerned about the inflation ticking up to B/ or even into recession. New loans will be more expensive and fewer (and as such press up the net interest margin). When are inflation levels no longer modest? Again this is impossible to judge exactly. Generally I think consensus would be that modest is usually max around 5% - a short period of between 5% and 10% might be ok, but not long term - the economy cannot adjust fast enough. Above 10% is very problematic - we are now heading towards recession inducing territory. Which gets us to the next section.  B/ Net effect of shock changes and long-term high inflation: A short-term rapid ascent of inflation (and then hopefully arrested by central bank actions) is almost self-evidently not good. People, businesses and lenders get caught out and you will see a short-term increase in defaults. If this ascent was just a shock, then it will move back to normal and perhaps these defaults can in fact be recovered in a more stable inflationary situation. Post a shock the credit market will contract and, potentially, almost dry-up for a while out of concern of another shock happening longer term. In the case of high-inflation everybody is having a hard time keeping pace adjusting. It can go either way in terms of effect on lending. Very likely, though, into increasing defaults and a lot of workouts - not necessarily ultimately net negative in terms of results. Certainly a contracting and expensive credit market. As mentioned, at some point, this type of inflationary situation would push the world into recession (for a short or long period). You will from the “line of defence” list see that Lusitano has material shock absorbers - dialled to resist exceptional shocks (all portfolios are stress tested against the worst shocks experienced over the past many years: Covid, Financial Crisis, Housing Crisis, Brexit etc) - and our capital/asset protection package, our strategic choice of portfolios to work with and direct control package should allow us to steer well clear of losses from even the high-inflation case.  Dynamics of Recession & Lending It is well-known that lending has issues with recession: defaults will go up proportionally to the size and length of the recession. Now for Lusitano the question is how much up will these defaults go, and in which industries/credit classes? As you can see from our line of defence, we have put ourselves quite far back in the capital exposure and we have made some serious strategic choices in respect of whom and what industry we support based upon their ability to weather a recession. And remember we have stress tested all portfolios for key crisis situations we can imagine. This means we feel reasonably confident about seeing our portfolios entering into a recession (not happy though). We actually don’t think we’d see ultimate losses in a recession unless it were to be very very long (which we think is unlikely given the central bank’s fierce commitments combating this) How do we navigate through a recession in terms of underwriting further/new credit? Remember we are doing “at-will” underwriting per individual loan and so we can act exceptionally fast in reducing and changing exposures. And this is where the skills and experience of a seasoned management team truly kicks into gear. All the senior members of the team have been through these situations before and know where to stop and withdraw from, where to keep a trickle with new underwriting guidelines and where to continue healthy volumes from etc… In fact, a nimble, highly skilled wholesale funder, can, as banks usually over-contract, build a strong franchise quite nicely in recessionary circumstances.  Originator/Lender & Asymmetry: Not necessarily your friend in crisis A key question to ask oneself, as a wholesale funder of lenders, is: Can you trust the lender/originator to act in a manner aligned with your interest in these cases of inflation/recession/crisis? Unfortunately the answer is, on balance, no. There are too many asymmetries in the relationship. We here list a few:   Lenders Junior/equity positions are not aligned with senior positions when crisis starts hollowing out a junior/equity position (junior position holder become more risk seeking than risk averse)   Lenders preservation of a long-term, multi-product, life-time revenue, customer relationship is not aligned with a specific loan’s performance and our position herein (as funder).   Lenders need for a constant volume of origination income/revenue is not aligned with our need for careful contraction of lending volume as market circumstances changes   Lenders larger RoE on Origination vs on Lending means decision-making is not aligned with our pure lending-based RoE.   I recently saw this graph from McKinsey below, which somewhat illustrates how this misalignment has, broadly speaking, only been increasing as lenders have moved towards “asset-light” business models (for good strategic reasons btw!). This graph speaks of banking, but it is the same for non-bank lenders - just worse (they are even more asset-light).  1372×968 111 KB  The point being, we cannot rely on the lender/originator acting in our interest in these situations of crisis, and therefore, we have installed the above detailed lines of defence. And put people in place who know how to use them.  Conclusion: Well-prepared & All-weather We hope we have shown you that we are well-prepared and setup for performing during inflation, crisis or recession. Having tracked the progression of the Monetalis Lusitano proposal from inception to its current state, we would raise the following concerns about the investment: Facility Structure:  Lack of first loss capital at the facility level  A 15-20% first loss position insulates Maker from principal losses on the underlying pool. First loss capital helps to shorten the duration of investment in the event that Maker chooses to wind down the portfolio   Limited excess spread  Net of fees and expenses, there is little excess spread generated to cover principal losses   Off market return  The facility has been proposed with a 2.00% stability fee and 10-year duration; the current 10-year US treasury rate is ~2.75%; the 2-year treasury rate is ~2.60%    Team  Understaffed for investing  The proposal requires knowledge on a range of different business models and collateral types; the Monetalis team is not specialized in this niche (looking at past proposals, the investment scope seems unfocused)   Understaffed for operations  The operational burden of tracking loan performance and compliance across different originators is formidable   Sourcing in a large, competitive marketplace is challenging  Incumbents have deep inroads in the space and more capital; originators have an incentive to prefer incumbents    While we are happy to see that this proposal has improved from its initial form (especially the proposal for a junior first-loss piece), we would still advise against the current iteration of this proposal. There seemingly are outsized structural and executional risks that are not appropriate for Maker. Moreover, we agree with @luca_pro on team bandwidth concerns for this strategy. This concern extends to the Maker core team as well, as this proposal is high touch and may require outsized resources to successfully monitor. As a broader consideration, we are of the opinion that the best assets for Maker are short duration and managed through an external DeFi protocol (Centrifuge, TrueFi, Maple, etc.). Shorter duration assets naturally pair better with Maker’s liquidity needs and external protocols can help to streamline the workflow/reporting for Maker.
